goals.label: To use research to inform knowledge of stable structures. (How can we test mock ups inspired by Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe?)
goals.educatordescription: To use research to inform knowledge of stable structures. (How can we test mock ups inspired by Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe?)
goals.peopledescription: To use research to inform knowledge of stable structures.
goals.exemplar:
Imagine you are building a cool playhouse, and you want to make sure it's the best playhouse ever! Testing mock-ups inspired by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe is like trying out different ideas for your playhouse to see which one is the most awesome.

Here's how you can do it:

  1. Look at the Design:

    • Take a good look at how the playhouse looks. Is it simple and not too complicated? Mies van der Rohe liked things to be simple and neat, so you want your playhouse to be that way too.

  2. Check the Materials:

    • Think about what materials you want to use. Mies van der Rohe liked using strong and clear materials, like really clear windows. Maybe you can use materials that are tough and see-through, like plastic or glass.

  3. Make Sure It's Easy to Play In:

    • Test if it's easy to play inside the playhouse. Can you move around easily? Mies van der Rohe wanted people to feel comfortable in the spaces he designed, so you want your playhouse to be super comfy for playing.

  4. Try Different Furniture:

    • Think about what furniture to put in your playhouse. Mies van der Rohe designed cool furniture too, like fancy chairs. Try different types of chairs and tables to see which ones make your playhouse look amazing.

  5. See How the Light Comes In:

    • Mies van der Rohe liked sunlight coming into his buildings. Check if the sunlight comes into your playhouse in a nice way. Maybe you can have big windows or openings for the sunlight to shine in.

  6. Ask Your Friends for Ideas:

    • Get your friends to play in your playhouse and ask them what they think. Do they like how it looks? Is it easy to play in? Your friends might have awesome ideas to make your playhouse even better!

  7. Make Changes if Needed:

    • If something doesn't feel right, don't worry! You can change it. Mies van der Rohe always made sure everything looked perfect, so you can keep trying different things until your playhouse is just the way you want it.

Remember, testing mock-ups is like trying out different versions of your playhouse until you find the one that's the most fun, comfortable, and looks the coolest!

goals.label: Pupils should be taught to plan their writing by in writing narratives, considering how authors have developed characters and settings in what pupils have read, listened to or seen performed
goals.educatordescription: Pupils should be taught to plan their writing by in writing narratives, considering how authors have developed characters and settings in what pupils have read, listened to or seen performed
goals.peopledescription: plan your written narratives.
goals.exemplar:
Let's create an example based on a classic story, "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" by Lewis Carroll. In this case, we'll plan a narrative based on a character and setting inspired by the original work.

Title: "The Mysterious Tea Party"

  1. Character Development:

    • Protagonist: Your protagonist could be a modern-day teenager named Alex who, like Alice, is curious, imaginative, and open to new experiences. Alex might find themselves transported to a magical world by falling through a portal, just like Alice fell down the rabbit hole.

    • Supporting Characters: Introduce a group of quirky and memorable characters that parallel those from "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland." For example, you could have a charismatic Cheshire Cat-like character, a mad tea-party host, and a White Rabbit-like character who guides Alex through the strange land.

  2. Setting Development:

    • Wonderland-Inspired World: Create a whimsical and fantastical setting that is reminiscent of Wonderland. The landscape should be surreal, filled with bizarre plants, talking animals, and peculiar landmarks. Perhaps there's a never-ending tea party taking place at the heart of this world, similar to the Mad Hatter's tea party in the original story.

    • Time and Place: Establish that this magical world operates on its own time and rules, and that Alex must navigate through it to find their way back home. The setting can be an enchanting, timeless realm accessible through a hidden door or an unusual object.

  3. Plot Outline:

    • Introduction: Start the story with Alex feeling out of place in their mundane life and stumbling upon the portal to the magical world. The journey begins as they enter this strange land.

    • Rising Action: As Alex explores the world, they encounter the eccentric characters and experience the unique customs of this place. Each encounter reveals a piece of the world's mysteries and quirks.

    • Climax: A significant event or challenge should push Alex to make a decision that will impact their journey, possibly involving a quest or mission to find a way back home.

    • Falling Action: As Alex gets closer to their goal, they come to understand the nature of this world and its inhabitants better. Important lessons and insights are learned.

    • Conclusion: The story should conclude with Alex's return to the real world, having gained a deeper appreciation for the ordinary, yet having been forever changed by their extraordinary adventure.

By planning your narrative with character and setting development inspired by established works like "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland," you can create a unique and captivating story that draws on the richness of classic literature while adding your own creative twists.
